topic.title: Clocking Use Cases

body.p: In the sections below, we will cover a range of clocking use-case examples using a 96 100-lane device and illustrate some optimal clocking configurations. This section is not intended to be an exhaustive list, but rather a way to capture some common clocking use-cases for analysis and discussion.

row.entry: Single Host: Common clock from host to switch; Common clock from host to EPs
Single Host: Common clock from host to switch; Common clock from switch to EPs
Single Host: Common clock from host to switch; SRIS/SRNS from switch to EPs
Single Host: SRIS/SRNS from host to switch; Common clock from switch to EPs
Single Host: SRIS/SRNS from host to switch; SRIS/SRNS from switch to EPs
Multi-Host: Common clock from host to switch; SRIS/SRNS from switch to EPs
Multi-Host: SRIS/SRNS from host to switch; SRIS/SRNS from switch to EPs

Multi-Host: SRIS/SRNS from host to switch; Common clock from switch to EPs

entry.p: Single Host: Common clock from host to switch; Common clock from switch to EPs; Two management hosts
Single Host: Common clock from host to switch; Common clock from switch to EPs; Two endpoints Endpoints on management stack

section.title: Case 0: Single Host: Common clock from clock generator to host, switch, and EPs
section.p: The following figure illustrates a case where a clock generator provides the reference clock to the host, switch and EPs. In this case the generator provides clock to REFCLK_D as non-SSC and has the option to provide SSC clock to the host and REFCLK_H on the switch.

This represents a legacy common clocking PCIe system. The generator distributes the clock to the host, switch downstream and upstream ports as well as the EP devices. The switch PCIE_REFCLK_D is used here to clock the switch core, CPU and peripherals. The local reference PCIE_REFCLK_D is not used to clock upstream or downstream ports on any of the stacks.

fig.title: Single Host: Common clock from clock generator to host, switch, and EPs

section.title: Case 1: Single Host: Common clock from host to switch; Common clock from switch to EPs
section.p: The following figure illustrates a case where the host provides a common clock to the switch. The switch also provides a common clock to the downstream drives.

This is a common use case for systems that use common clocking from the host to the switch. It has a greatly simplified clock distribution on the board since the switch is able to take care of common clocking outputs to the drives. It is important to note that in this use case, the host provided clock is not phase aligned with the drive clock since the switch is not passing the host clock through. Instead, the switch is providing a common clock derived from PCIE_REFCLK_D.
The switch PCIE_REFCLK_D pin in this case provides clock to the switch core, CPU, peripherals, and the downstream ports.

fig.title: Single Host: Common clock from host to switch; Common clock from switch to EPs

section.title: Case 2: Single Host: Common clock from host to switch; SRIS/SRNS from switch to EPs
section.p: The following figure illustrates a case where the host uses one of PCIE_REFCLK_H* inputs to provide a common clock to the switch upstream port. The SSDs are clocked off their own reference clock.
The switch output clocks are therefore not used and the PCIE_REFCLK_D is used to clock the switch core, CPU, and low speed peripherals.

fig.title: Single Host: Common clock from host to switch; SRIS/SRNS from switch to EPs

section.title: Case 3: Single Host: SRIS/SRNS from host to switch; Common clock from switch to EPs
section.p: The following figure illustrates a case where the connection between host to switch uses separate clocking (SRIS/SRNS) and the switch to EP connection uses common clocking.
This is a common use-case for a host connection to multiple M.2 devices which inherently use common clocking. In this case, the host is clocked by a local refclk.

The switch uses its own local REFCLK (PCIE_REFCLK_D) to provide clocking for the switch core, the upstream port, the downstream ports to the common clocked drives, the CPU and any low speed peripherals.

fig.title: Single Host: SRIS/SRNS from host to switch; Common clock from switch to EPs

section.title: Case 4: Single Host: SRIS/SRNS from host to switch; SRIS/SRNS from switch to EPs
section.p: The following figure illustrates the case where the host to switch and switch to drive connections all use separate clocking (SRIS/SRNS).

The host has its own local REFCLK as do each of the SSDs in the topology. In this case, the PCIE_REFCLK_D provides clocking for only the switch core, upstream/downstream posts, CPU, and peripherals. This is the simplest configuration in terms of clocking complexity at the board level.

fig.title: Single Host: SRIS/SRNS from host to switch; SRIS/SRNS from switch to EPs

section.title: Case 5: Multi-Host: Common clock from host to switch; SRIS/SRNS from switch to EPs
section.p: The following figure illustrates a case where multiple hosts supply common clocks to the switch upstream ports while the PCIE_REFCLK_D proves clocks for the switch downstream ports. The drives in this case have local refclks.
Note that in this use case, stack 3 has been used to support host 2. This change has meant that CSU3 has taken over clocking responsibility for downstream ports in stack 4.

fig.title: Multi-Host: Common clock from host to switch; SRIS/SRNS from switch to EPs

section.title: Case 6: Multi-Host: SRIS/SRNS from host to switch; SRIS/SRNS from switch to EPs
section.p: The following figure illustrates a case where multiple hosts are connected to switch. The hosts each have local refclks using SRIS or SRNS. The drives also use local refclks. The switch PCIE_REFCLK_D is used to clock the switch core, the upstream/downstream ports, the CPU, and peripherals.

fig.title: Multi-Host: SRIS/SRNS from host to switch; SRIS/SRNS from switch to EPs

section.title: Case 7: Multi-Host: Common clock from host to switch; Common clock from switch to EPs
section.p: The following figure illustrates a case where multiple hosts using common clocking are connected through the switch to drives which also use common clocking. In this case, the common clocks to the drives are sourced by the switch and are therefore not phase aligned with the host REFCLK input.
The switch PCIE_REFCLK_D is used to supply clocks to the switch core, the downstream ports, CPU, and low speed peripherals.

fig.title: Multi-Host: Common clock from host to switch; Common clock from switch to EPs

section.title: Case 8: Multi-Host: SRIS/SRNS from host to switch; Common clock from switch to EPs
section.p: The following figure illustrates a case where multiple hosts use separate clocking to the switch. The switch uses common clocking to the drives.
This is a multi-host version of the common M.2 use-case covered in case3. The PCIE_REFCLK_D clocks the switch core, upstream ports, downstream ports, CPU, and low speed peripherals.

fig.title: Multi-Host: SRIS/SRNS from host to switch; Common clock from switch to EPs

section.title: Case 9: Single Host: Legacy Common clock from host to switch PCIE_REFCLK_D; Common clock from host to EPs
section.p: The following figure illustrates a case where the host provides a common clock to the switch REFCLK_D input. The host also provides a common clock to the downstream drives.

This represents a legacy common clocking PCIe system. The host distributes the clock to the switch core reference clock which then clocks the downstream and upstream ports. Through a buffer, the host clock is also distributed to the EP devices. The switch PCIE_REFCLK_D is sourced by the host and REFCLK_D is used to clock the USP and DSPs.

note.p: If the host is used to clock the switch REFCLK_D, the host may not generate SSC. The switch REFCLK_D should have a no-SSC clock.

fig.title: Single Host: Legacy Common clock from host to switch PCIE_REFCLK_D; Common clock from host to EPs

section.title: Case 10: Single Host: Common clock from host to switch; Common clock from switch to EPs; Two management hosts
section.p: The following figure illustrates a case where the host provides a common clock to the switch. The switch also provides a common clock to the downstream drives. There are two management hosts running their own common clock to the switch.

This is a common use case for systems that use common clocking from the host to the switch. It has a greatly simplified clock distribution on the board since the switch is able to take care of common clocking outputs to the drives. It is important to note that in this use case, the host provided clock is not phase aligned with the drive clock since the switch is not passing the host clock through. Instead, the switch is providing a common clock derived from PCIE_REFCLK_D.
The switch PCIE_REFCLK_D pin in this case provides clock to the switch core, CPU, peripherals, and the downstream ports.

fig.title: Single Host: Common clock from host to switch; Common clock from switch to EPs; Two management hosts

section.title: Case 11: Single Host: Common clock from host to switch; Common clock from switch to EPs; Two endpoints Endpoints on management stack
section.p: The following figure illustrates a case where the host provides a common clock to the switch. The switch also provides a common clock to the downstream drives. There are two management hosts running their own common clock to the switch. There are two endpoints Endpoints connected to the management stack (2x2) and taking common clock from PCIE_REFCLK_S6.

This is a common use case for systems that use common clocking from the host to the switch. It has a greatly simplified clock distribution on the board since the switch is able to take care of common clocking outputs to the drives. It is important to note that in this use case, the host provided clock is not phase aligned with the drive clock since the switch is not passing the host clock through. Instead, the switch is providing a common clock derived from PCIE_REFCLK_D.
The switch PCIE_REFCLK_D pin in this case provides clock to the switch core, CPU, peripherals, and the downstream ports.

fig.title: Single Host: Common clock from host to switch; Common clock from switch to EPs; Two endpoints Endpoints on management stack
